main event: On July 28, 1956, in Commerce, Michigan, a bright light, sometimes flashing, was observed at arms length over the horizon for 1 hour and 45 minutes by several civilian observers. The light faded gradually and disappeared, remaining stationary throughout the observation.
interesting points: The observation lasted for a significant duration of 1 hour and 45 minutes.
The source of the report was a civilian source associated with the Ground-Radar.
The conclusion of the report was that there was insufficient data for evaluation, indicating an open determination on the nature of the sighting.
The report mentioned that the physical characteristics of the subject were not available, indicating the limitations of the observation.
Witness name mentioned in the report is Lawrence Richardson, adding a personal touch to the observation.
